Column Comment.0: SAMPLE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample used in technical analysis.
Column Comment.1: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.2: BASE MEASURED DEPTH: The bottom or lower depth from which this sample iscollected. In well drilling, the bottom of the well is the base measured depth and thisdepth is used as the lower limit in calculating the total length of the well.
Column Comment.3: BASE MEASURED DEPTH ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original units ofmeasure used to measure to the bottom of the total length of the well(e.g., meter,kilometer, mile, yard, etc).
Column Comment.4: BASE STRATIGRAPHY UNIT IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a stratigraphy unitat the bottom of the well.
Column Comment.5: COLLECTED BY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier that canbe used to distinguish the business associate that collected the sample.
Column Comment.6: COLLECTED_DATE: The date the sample was collected. In cases where thecollection process takes more than one day, the date when the first portion of thesample is collected is used.
Column Comment.7: COLLECTED EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier that distinguishes theparticular equipment used in the collection process. Specific information regardingthe equipment can be found in the equipment database (equipment service dates,warranties, parts, etc).
Column Comment.8: COLLECTED FOR BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Identifier for the businessassociate that the sample(s) was collected for (e.g. Individual, department, company,government, etc).
Column Comment.9: COLLECTED TIME: The time at which the first portion of the sample is collected.
Column Comment.10: COLLECTION PHASE TYPE: The phase of a sample at collection time, usually solid,gas or liquid. The phase of a sample may change from its original location as it iscollected, stored and analyzed (e.g. methane, ethane, propane). Note: During welldepletion the pressure will drop which can result in a phase change, this is a phasechange at collection. C1 to C3 hydrocarbons may phase change during storage if thetemperature and pressure are different from that of the well, this is phase change atstorage. Pyrolysis results in a phase change of the sample during analysis.
Column Comment.11: COLLECTION PRESSURE: The pressure at which the sample is collected. In welldrilling this would be the well pressure.
Column Comment.13: COLLECTION TEMPERATURE: The temperature at which the sample is collected.In well drilling this would be the well temperature.
Column Comment.15: COLLECTION TEST TYPE: Various tests are used in the collection process. Forexample true isokinetic sample capture at the middle of the pipeline, or samplecollection from the bottom of the pipeline, or bottom hole pressure test.
Column Comment.16: SAMPLE ANALYSIS COLLECTION TYPE: The type of collection method used forgathering this sample, such as for daily tests, weekly tests, spot analysis, etc.
Column Comment.17: COMPOSITE SAMPLE COUNT: The number of samples that are blended or used inorder to create a single composite sample. This number should always be a wholenumber.
Column Comment.18: COMPOSITE SAMPLE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this sample is acomposite sample. Composite samples are constructed by combining portions ofother samples. Full information about which samples are used as input to this oneare derived from SAMPLE ORIGIN.
Column Comment.19: CONDENSED SECTION INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this section is acondensed section. In condensed sections, fossils and organic materials tend to bemore concentrated than in rapidly deposited sections. May be deposited duringtransgressions and associated with "maximum flooding surfaces". These formimportant sequence stratigraphic markers.
Column Comment.20: CURRENT LENGTH: The current length of the sample after any subsamples havebeen removed from it for analysis or due to loss because of sample crumbling. Thisvalue is a running value which is calculated by removing any subsample or loss fromthe INITIAL_LENGTH. This value should be updated every time the sample lengthchanges. The subsample length being removed can be found in the SAMPLEORIGIN table and is known as the PORTION_LENGTH.
Column Comment.22: CURRENT LENGTH PERCENT: The percentage of length remaining from the totallength. This is calculated using the current length divided by the total length multipliedby 100%. This percentage should be updated every time the current lengthchanges.This can be compared to the INITIAL_LENGTH_PERCENT for a quickreference to how much sample is left.
Column Comment.23: CURRENT VOLUME: The current volume of the sample after any subsamples havebeen removed from it for analysis or due to loss because of sample spillage. Thisvalue is a running value which is calculated by removing any subsample or loss fromthe initial volume. This value should be updated every time the sample volumechanges. The subsample volume being removed can be found in the SAMPLEORIGIN table and is known as the PORTION_VOLUME.
Column Comment.24: CURRENT VOLUME ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measureused for the current volume measurement. Note: because this value results viacalculation the unit should be similar to that of the initial volume and the subsamples.Common units are m^3, L or mL.
Column Comment.25: CURRENT VOLUME PERCENT: The percentage of volume remaining from the totalvolume. This is calculated using the current volume divided by the total volumemultiplied by 100%. This percentage should be updated every time the currentvolume changes. This can be compared to the INITIAL_VOLUME_PERCENT for aquick reference to how much sample is left.
Column Comment.26: CURRENT WEIGHT: The current weight or mass of the sample after processing andpreparation. This value is a running value which is calculated by removing anysubsample or loss from the initial weight. This value should be updated every timethe sample weight changes. The subsample weight being removed can be found inthe SAMPLE ORIGIN table and is known as the PORTION_WEIGHT.
Column Comment.27: CURRENT WEIGHT ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measureused for the current weight measurement. Note: because this value results viacalculation the unit should be similar to that of the initial weight and the subsamples.Common units are oz, lb, kg, tonne.
Column Comment.28: CURRENT WEIGHT PERCENT: The percentage of weight remaining from the totalweight. This is calculated using the current weight divided by the total weightmultiplied by 100%. This percentage should be updated every time the current weightchanges. This can be compared to the INITIAL_WEIGHT_PERCENT for a quickreference to how much sample is left.
Column Comment.29: CYLINDER PRESSURE: Pressure of the sample storage cylinder. This plays a rolein the phase change of the sample.
Column Comment.30: CYLINDER PRESSURE ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit ofmeasure used for the cylinder pressure. This is usually in psi or atm.
Column Comment.31: CYLINDER TEMPERATURE: Temperature of the storage cylinder. This plays a rolein the phase change of the sample.
Column Comment.32: CYLINDER TEMPERATURE ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit ofmeasure used for the cylinder temperature. This is usually in deg. C or K.
Column Comment.33: DESTROYED DATE: The date that this sample is physically destroyed.
Column Comment.34: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first comes into effect.
Column Comment.35: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row is no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.36: INITIAL LENGTH: The initial length is the length of the samples taken from the entiresample before any processing and preparation. This is a representative sample of theTOTAL_LENGTH.
Column Comment.38: INITIAL LENGTH PERCENT: The initial length percent is the SAMPLE_LENGTHdivided by the TOTAL_LENGTH multiplied by 100%. In core drilling, the samplescollected are only a small portion of the total length as it would be unreasonable tocollect theentire core.
Column Comment.39: INITIAL VOLUME: The initial volume is the volume of the samples taken from theentire sample before any processing and preparation. This is a representative sampleof the TOTAL_VOLUME.
Column Comment.40: INITIAL VOLUME ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measureused for the initial volume. Common units are m^3, L or mL.
Column Comment.41: INITIAL VOLUME PERCENT: The initial volume percent is initial volume divided bythe total volume multiplied by 100%.
Column Comment.42: INITIAL WEIGHT: The initial weight of the sample that is procured from the entiresample before any preparation or processing. If using SAMPLE ORIGIN, this value isthe sum of the PORTION WEIGHT values.
Column Comment.43: INITIAL WEIGHT ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measure usedfor the initial weight measurement. Note: because this value results via calculationthe unit should be similar to that of the individual components or if using SAMPLEORIGINthe unit should be similar to that of the PORTION WEIGHT. Common unitsare oz, lb, kg, tonne.
Column Comment.44: INITIAL WEIGHT PERCENT: The initial weight percent is the initial weight divided bythe total weight multiplied by 100%. This information helps determine how much ofthe whole sample has been procured for representation.
Column Comment.45: PERCENT OF THE INTERVAL COLLECTED: Of the complete interval described bythe top and base depths, the percent over which samples were collected.
Column Comment.46: OIL STAINED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether there are hydrocarbonspresent or not.
Column Comment.47: PHYSICAL ITEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for the physical item that containsthe actual sample. In some cases, the sample is divided into portions; in this case,each portion is described in SAMPLE_ORIGIN and a foreign key from RMPHYSICAL ITEM identifies the location of the sample itself. Note that these foreignkeys are provided as a denormalized column. The nominal location for thisinformation is RM_INFO_ITEM_CONTENT.
Column Comment.48: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.49: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.50: REPORTED MUD DESCRIPTION: A description of the drilling mud, taking intoaccount the type of mud(clay, polymer or foam), any chemicals used on themud(Sodium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, lime, etc), viscosity of the mud, etc.
Column Comment.51: REPORTED RESEVOIR PRESSURE: The pressure of the reservoir that is reportedat the time of collection, there are various methods to measure the pressure. Thebest measurement is made by bottomhole testing with adequate shut-in time.
Column Comment.52: REPORTED RESEVOIR PRESSURE ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The originalunit of measure used in the measurement of the pressure of the reservoir. Commonunits are psi or atm.
Column Comment.53: SAMPLE COUNT: The quantity of samples collected that the total sample iscomprised of.
Column Comment.54: SAMPLE DIAMETER: The diameter of the sample, particularly when created from acore sample. Special core bits are used to remove the cores.
Column Comment.55: SAMPLE DIAMETER ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measureused in the measurement of the diameter of core samples. Common units are inches.
Column Comment.56: SAMPLE INTERVAL: The interval at which sample portions are taken. In theparticular case of core samples, the intervals are used to reduce the amount of rockcore that would be needed to be stored.
Column Comment.57: SAMPLE INTERVAL ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measureused for the intervals between samples collected. Common units are meters or feet.
Column Comment.58: SAMPLE QUALITY: The overall quality of the sample taken, such as good, fair, poor.Generally, quality decreases in this order: whole core, sidewall core, cuttings oroutcrop samples.
Column Comment.59: SAMPLE QUALITY DESCRIPTION: Narrative description of the quality of the samplein general. Note that this observation may or may not be the same as the observationnoted during a particular analysis, as the sample itself may have different properties,or the observer may be noting different aspects of the condition of the sample. Forexample, a sample that is noted to be in good condition in general (approproate foranalysis) may be qualified as biodegraded during geochemical analysis.
Column Comment.60: REFERENCE NUMBER: the number or identifier given to this sample portion in thefield for identification purposes. For legal reasons, this number accompanies thesample together with a chain of custody (in the RM module) to show provenance.
Column Comment.61: SAMPLE SHAPE TYPE: The shape of the sample, such as cylindrical, square,oblong, amorphous, rectangular, slice, random, etc.
Column Comment.62: SAMPLE TYPE: The type of sample that is described. For example, whole core,sidewall core, cuttings or outcrop samples.
Column Comment.63: SAMPLE WIDTH: The width of the sample, most commonly used when the sample isa cubic form. For example in maceral analysis the sample is cut into cube beforeanalysis.
Column Comment.64: SAMPLE WIDTH ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE:
Column Comment.65: SEPARATOR PRESSURE: The pressure inside the separator drum. Manipulation ofthe pressure in the separator could be used to separate the different hydrocarbons inthe crude mixture.
Column Comment.66: SEPARATOR PRESSURE ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit ofmeasure used for the measurement of the pressure in the separator. Common unit ispsi.
Column Comment.67: SEPARATOR TEMPERATURE: The temperature inside the separator drum.Manipulation of the temperature in the separator could be used to separate thedifferent hydrocarbons in the crude mixture.
Column Comment.68: SEPARATOR TEMPERATURE ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit ofmeasure used for the temperature in the drum. Common units are deg. C or K.
Column Comment.69: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.70: STORED EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for the equipment used tostore the samples. For example, fridge, cylinder, tank, etc.
Column Comment.71: SAMPLE PHASE TYPE: The phase of a sample during storage, usually solid, gas orliquid. The phase of a sample may change from its original location as it is collected,stored and analyzed (e.g. methane, ethane, propane). Note: During well depletion thepressure will drop which can result in a phase change, this is a phase change atcollection. C1 to C3 hydrocarbons may phase change during storage if thetemperature and pressure are different from that of the well, this is phase change atstorage. Pyrolysis results in a phase change of the sampleduring analysis.
Column Comment.72: STRAT NAME SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the stratigraphic name set. Astratigraphic name set is an unordered collection of stratigraphic units, that may be inuse for a Lexicon, a geographic area, a project, a company, etc.
Column Comment.73: SUB SAMPLE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this sample contains asubsample or a portion of an original, parent sample. This information is important,since samples may not be fully homogeneous in form or content. As a consequence,studies done on different subsamples from the same parent sample may result indifferent analysis results. Information about how samples and sub samples arerelated to each other is captured in SAMPLE ORIGIN.
Column Comment.74: TOP MEASURED DEPTH: The top or upper depth from which this sample wascollected. This depth is used as the upper limit in the total length of the sample.
Column Comment.75: TOP MEASURED DEPTH ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit ofmeasure used for the top depth. Common units are meters or feet.
Column Comment.76: TOP STRATIGRAPHY UNIT IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a stratigraphy unitat the top of the well.
Column Comment.77: TOTAL LENGTH: The total length is the length of the entire sample before therepresentative sample is procured from it. The representative sample data iscollected as the INITIAL_LENGTH. In well coring, the TOTAL_LENGTH is the lengthof the core from the based depth to the top depth. In this case the total length can bevery long. The INITIAL_LENGTH is the length of the samples that are removed at thesample intervals. These are analyzed or stored.
Column Comment.78: TOTAL LENGTH ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measure usedfor the total sample length. Common units are meters or feet.
Column Comment.79: TOTAL VOLUME: The total volume is the volume of the entire sample before therepresentative sample is procured from it. The representative sample data iscollected as the INITIAL_VOLUME. In liquid sampling, the TOTAL_VOLUME is thevolume of the entire extracted fluid. In this case the total volume can be very large.The INITIAL_VOLUME is the volume of the samples that are removed at the sampleintervals. These are analyzed or stored.
Column Comment.80: TOTAL VOLUME ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE: The original unit of measure usedfor the total sample volume. Common units are m^3, L or mL.
Column Comment.81: TOTAL WEIGHT: The total weight is the weight of the entire sample before therepresentative sample is procured from it. The representative sample data iscollected as the INITIAL_WEIGHT. In well coring, the TOTAL_WEIGHT is the weightof the core from the base depth to the top depth. In this case the total weight can bevery heavy. The INITIAL_WEIGHT is the weight of the samples that are removed atthe sample intervals.
Column Comment.83: WELL DATUM TYPE: Identifies the various type of well datums that may be used aselevation reference datums. For example kelly bushing, ground, derrick floor, casingflange or sea level.
Column Comment.84: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.85: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.86: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.87: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.88: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.89: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.90: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
